page.title: 02Ecology,Earlston
page.content: The weather is usually mild but variable.There are a lot of footpaths in woods, by rivers and up the Black Hill which is a volcanic plug.The area has a variety of wild flowers by roadsides, hedgerows and river banks. The most common flowers being daisies, dandelions and forget-me-nots.There are a selection of deciduous trees such as sycamore and ash.Many elm were killed by Dutch Elm disease.There are also some conifer trees.Many birds like wood pigeons, crows, sparrows and pheasants live in hedges and woods. The vegetation provides cover for rabbits, hares, squirrels and deer. The farmers control weeds in fields by spraying but birds and animals can find food and shelter in hedgerows and wooded area.The River Leader,which is relatively unpolluted, has lots of fish like minnows,trout and salmon.
